captions.text: Hey it's me Destin. Welcome back to Smarter Every Day. Today we're gonna do awesome science with
Orbix Hot Glass here at Lookout Mountain Alabama. Goggle up.
Science is about to happen. We're gonna use a high speed camera and learn about Prince Rupert's Drop.
[whispers] It's never been done on the internet. You're gonna learn something.
Let's go.
OK we are here inside the shop with
Cal. Cal owns the place. Can you show me how to make a Prince Rupert's Drop?
(Cal) Sure. I'm gonna gather some glass, drop it in a bucket of
cold water.
[sizzling sound]
(Destin) So after it cools down, this is what you're left with.
It kinda looks like a tadpole, but it has some really interesting mechanical properties.
We can actually hit this thing with a hammer and it won't break.

OK I'm ready. [bang]
Didn't go.
OK I think Cal is kind of a pansy so I.. You think you can break it? [laugh]
So we're gonna try again only this time I'm gonna make him hit it really hard
and I'm gonna record it with high speed. Does that work? Think you can break it? Alright. Let's do it.

The challenge is on.
(Cal) Just hit it?
- Yep.

[bang] [shattering] [laughs]
So do you think you actually broke it? I don't think

you did. You think you broke it?
- I know I broke it. [laugh]
- Let's look at the high speed.
[music]
OK so the drop broke, but technically it wasn't the
hammer that broke it. If you look close in the high speed you can see that it's the wiggling of the
tail that makes it go. This is the mystery of the
Prince Rupert's Drop. You can try
as hard as you can to break the bulb, but you can't.
But, if you even nick the tail, the entire thing will explode. Not shatter,
but actually explode. Let's go outside and I'll show you more.
OK we're gonna just run an obscene frame rate here. We have this
Phantom V1610. So, glass breaking occurs
so fast that you have to have like hundreds of thousands of frames per second, so we're gonna
have a lower resolution and we have to have a lot of light as well. We're also gonna use this Miro over
here to run about 3000 frames per second so we can get a wide shot to see the whole event.

as well.
3..2..1.. go.
[shatter]
[Awesome Music by Gordon McGladdery}
OK now we understand what a Prince Rupert Drop does, but at this point
we don't quite understand why it does it. Let's take a closer look.
OK this is called a polariscope and basically what it is is it's a filtered piece of
glass that's polarized. I have another filter here. You can see if I turn it,
then I can block out the light. Now if I put this on the camera
that you're looking through here, and then I put the Prince Rupert's Drop in between
the two pieces of glass, you should be able to see the internal stresses built up
inside the Prince Rupert's Drop. So to understand how these stresses got here, let's
use the color grey to represent nice and strong solid glass. We use red
to represent molten glass and because of the thermal expansion coefficient it's safe to assume that the
higher the temperature the larger this glass wants to be. Blue represents glass that's cooling
off, or transitioning between the two states. Because of that same thermal expansion coefficient
this glass is shrinking and basically pulling in on itself. Think of a
Prince Rupert's Drop as a bunch of little infantessimal pieces of glass with each piece trying to interact
with the pieces around it. When the molten glass is first dripped into the water, the
outside layer touches the water and immediately solidifies. This locks in that
outside shape of the drop. The inside of the drop however is still a hot expanded
liquid. As heat's transferred to the water that glass on the inside slowly begins to
cool down, and pulls in against that outside layer. The problem is that
because it's already locked in as a round solid, it only compresses tighter against
itself. This actually makes it stronger. Kind of like how an arch compresses and gets stronger when
you put your weight on it only this is in all directions. And because the cooling glass can't
move that outside layer it begins to pull against itself, causing it to be
in extremely high tension. It then hardens in this state of tension and there you have it, a
Prince Rupert's Drop. The outside is in extremely high compressive stress and the inside is in
extremely high tensile stress. If one link in this tension chain is ever cut, it
breaks on down the line, feeding off of its own stored up energy just like a chemical
explosive does. The difference here is that instead of releasing chemical potential energy
mechanical strain energy is released. This wave of energy is what we call a
failure front. You can directly measure the velocity of that failure front as long as
you have a camera fast enough. Let's give it a shot at 130,000 frames

per second.
3..2..1..go.
Got it?
[music]
So a big thanks to Cal from Orbix Hot Glass. If you found this
interesting and you want to support him by buying stuff go click on the link, wherever I
put it, and go check out his web site. Click the cat to subscribe.
With the helmet. [laugh] It's a sad looking cat.

You've never caught the cat on fire, ever?
- Never.
- Not even once?

- Never.
- These things are named for a guy named Prince Rupert, imagine that,

who lived in Bavaria back in the 1600s.
Here, here.
[shins banging on concrete laughter through pain]
He brought these over as a gift to King Charles II in England who gave them to his

Royal Society to try to figure out.
Yep ready. [clang]
Holy smokes!

- Aah the tension's killing me. [shatter]
-(Destin in background) NO DON'T BLOW UP!

- You know it blow.. blowed up?
- Yep, it blowed up.
- It BLOWED UP Y'ALL! [laugh]

Captioning in different languages welcome.
Please contact Destin if you can help.

[ Captions by Andrew Jackson ]
captionsbyandrew.wordpress.com

comments.author: Eric Taylor

comments.text:
I was a welder. This is something you have to think about when welding, and 
engineers have to calculate the stresses induced by welding.
   If a weld has been done properly the welded unit never fails at the weld 
itself. The fracture happens NEXT to the weld, due to the stresses induced 
by the welding process.
  In structural welds you never let the metal cool too quickly (by 
quenching it) but when you're learning to welt you'll put a bunch of welds 
on the same piece of scrap. Quenching is common because these welds aren't 
going to be used for anything. I was surprised here because the glass bulb 
continues to glow for a lot longer than steal would. But then steel is 
quite a lot better at conducting heat so the heat in the steal moves into 
the water much more quickly than it would in glass.﻿

comments.text:
I've got a question for someone smart. From my understanding, the fastest a 
force can propogate through an object is at the speed of sound. For 
example, if you had a long, solid rod and flicked one end, the information 
telling the other end to move would travel through the rod at the speed of 
sound. So if this is true, why does this drop break at roughly 5 times the 
speed of sound? Do I have something totally wrong here?﻿
comments.author: Wes, the Bass Dude

comments.text:
+rammerstheman We're not confused at all.
 Harry was referring to my previous comment when I was using a magnifying 
glass as an illustration of how sound behaves differently in a different 
medium in a very similar way to how light does in a magnifying glass.
Your explanation about the speed of light is quite long, but amusing. I get 
the idea, however I've done some more reading on the subject and must 
reserve judgement as it gets into quantum mechanics. I can't be bothered 
with more than a passing curiosity.
Oh, and C is defined as "the speed of light in a vacuum" and is 299,792,458 
m s–1. In water light's speed is around 225,000,000 m s–1. In glass light's 
speed is around 200,000,000 m s–1.
My memory from high school physics was not in error. Whether involving 
"packets" or whatnot, the observable speed of light does in fact change in 
different mediums.
comments.author: Doken Boken

comments.text:
+Harry Balzak +Doken Boken  I think you're getting a little confused. C is 
the speed of light, and not the speed of sound. The speed of sound is much 
less than the speed of light in any case, this is why you see the flash of 
thunder before the clap. The speed of light is constant, and you're also 
correct that light takes more time to travel through different mediums, 
however the reasons behind this are extemely complex and mathematical, and 
in reality aren't the same as taking a longer route. It's late and so it's 
the perfect time to have a go at explaining this. In reality, the beam 
light is still traveling at C, however the light clusters together as a 
thing called a wave packet, and this wave packet moves slower than the 
light does. It's the wave packet that you observe as your light traveling 
through the material. Imagine a line of people running forward at C, the 
guy at the front is carrying a bottle of light with a parachute attached, 
as he is running forward the wind pulls the bottle back, but  he is not 
able to slow down, so he has to pass the bottle back. If you were to 
measure the speed of the guy, it's C, but the light bottle is moving 
slower. Different mediums ie glass, water, air, have a stronger wind 
blowing on the bottle, so the light bottle will move at different speeds, 
but only ever slower than the guys/ under C. The guys are the light, and 
bottle is the wave packet. What's a bit odd is in reality, once the guy has 
passed the bottle back, he'll dissapear, so err maybe it's a bottle of 
life, I dunno. But If you even vaguely understood that then you've done 
seriously well, cuz I'm not quite sure if I do either!
comments.author: rammerstheman

comments.text:
+Harry Balzak You're right, for the most part, but I'd like to point your 
attention to this: 
http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/story?id=99111 I'm fairly certain that's 
not simply a longer path.
comments.author: Doken Boken

comments.text:
+Doken Boken C is constant. You can force light to travel a longer path 
through an object, but C remains the same.
comments.author: Harry Balzak

comments.text:
Generally, the easiest way of understanding it is that the speed of sound 
varies, and the greater an objects density the faster sound will travel 
through it. So the speed of sound in air is what people generally refer to, 
but it's MUCH greater in glass or steel. People have done experiments to 
show this by sending sound through air for a distance, and several other 
mediums for a vastly greater distance, and them all reaching the end at the 
same time. However, you wouldn't be able to understand any language because 
our ears are adapted specifically to sound in air, but the sound still 
travels much more efficiently because objects of a greater density have 
their particles more closely placed together and make it easier for the 
sound to transfer its energy between them.
comments.author: MegaBlazewing

comments.text:
The speed of sound in glass is ~4000 m/s, which would be the upper limit 
for the rate it would break at. In this case the actual velocity its about 
1/2 that.
comments.author: mysock351C

comments.text:
Rammerstheman is absolutely correct. The speed of sound is variable, 
depending on the medium.
So is the speed of light to some extent. That's why eye-glasses and 
magnifying lenses work.
comments.author: Doken Boken

comments.text:
You're exactly right. However the 'speed of sound' that people talk about 
(300m/s) is the speed of sound through air. The speed of sound through 
other mediums, water, glass, dirt, is different, and in most cases a lot 
faster. Google it for yourslef... 'Speed of sound through glass etc'
